text.headline: Alan Turing and the Turing Test: A Timeline
text.text: Explore the life of Alan Turing and the development of the Turing Test, a foundational concept in artificial intelligence.

text.headline: Birth of Alan Turing
text.text: Alan Mathison Turing was born in Maida Vale, London. He would go on to become one of the most influential figures in mathematics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.

media.caption: Blue plaque commemorating Turing's birthplace in Maida Vale, London.

text.headline: Publishes the Turing Machine Concept
text.text: Turing publishes his groundbreaking paper 'On Computable Numbers,' introducing the Turing Machine, a foundational model for computation.

text.headline: Work at Bletchley Park
text.text: Turing plays a pivotal role in breaking the German Enigma code during World War II, significantly aiding the Allied war effort.

media.caption: Bletchley Park, where Turing worked during World War II.

text.headline: Publishes 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence'
text.text: Turing proposes the concept of the Turing Test in this seminal paper, posing the question, 'Can machines think?'

text.headline: Conviction and Prosecution
text.text: Turing is convicted of 'gross indecency' due to his homosexuality, leading to his chemical castration. This marked a tragic turn in his life.

media.caption: Statue of Alan Turing in Sackville Park, Manchester.

text.headline: Death of Alan Turing
text.text: Alan Turing dies from cyanide poisoning at the age of 41. While his death is widely believed to have been a suicide, the circumstances remain uncertain.

media.caption: Alan Turing's grave in Wilmslow Cemetery.

text.headline: Official Apology from the British Government
text.text: The British Prime Minister, Gordon Brown, issues an apology on behalf of the government for Turing's treatment.

media.caption: Gordon Brown, who issued the apology.

text.headline: Posthumous Pardon
text.text: Queen Elizabeth II grants a posthumous royal pardon to Alan Turing for his 1952 conviction.
